questions.text: 1. A mother brings her infant after noticing the child is dyspnoeic. An echocardiogram showed multiple masses in the ventricles causing obstruction to blood flow. Following surgical resection, the histopathologic reports of the mass showed spider cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An infant's echocardiogram showing multiple cardiac masses in the ventricle which on histopathology shows spider cells suggests a likely diagnosis of rhabdomyoma.

Rhabdomyomas are the most common pediatric primary cardiac tumor and are seen during the first years of life. They are commonly noted during evaluation for valvular or other flow obstructive causes. Around one-half of the cardiac rhabdomyomas are due to sporadic mutations while the other half are associated with tuberous sclerosis

They are gray-white myocardial masses that are usually multiple in number and are mostly seen involving the ventricles and protruding into the lumen. Microscopically, they consist of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Routine histologic processing removes the glycogen and artifactually reduces the cytoplasm to thin strands stretching from nucleus to surface membrane. These appear to look like spider cells. 

They are considered hamartomatous as they often undergo spontaneous regression. Surgical resection is only indicated if the tumors cause obstruction.

The image below shows histopathological findings of cardiac rhabdomyoma with spider cells.



Other options:

Option A: Papillary fibroelastomas are sea-anemone-shaped endocardial tumors and are mainly present on valves. They are usually incidental but become clinically important if they embolize.

Option B: Myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults. They are benign Unlike rhabdomyomas and single and the common site of origin is the region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an abundant acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. There are characteristic vessel-like or glandlike structures.

Option D: Paragangliomas are rare chromaffin cell tumors and are a form of extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma. They are highly vascular and can be hormonally active causing uncontrolled hypertension.

questions.text: 2. A 48-year-old male patient presented with a painless mass in the parotid region. Examination revealed a 5-cm rounded, well-demarcated tumor. Biopsy of the tumor revealed myoepithelial cells intermingled with myxoid, mucoid, and cartilaginous areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathological findings are suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms and the parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Therefore they are also termed mixed tumors.

Pathology:

Gross features:

* The tumors are rounded, well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm.

* They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate.

* The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.



On microscopy epithelial and mesenchymal components are visible. Epithelial components resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells that are arranged in the form of ducts, acini, irregular tubules, or sheets of cells. These components are dispersed in the mesenchymal components consisting of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing cartilage or bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).



Other options:

Option A: Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells. The inner layer contains columnar cells while the outer layer contains cuboidal cells.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma involves minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling swiss cheese.

Pearl PM1674: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

* Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma

* Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

* Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma

* Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

* Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma

* Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland

* Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma

* Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: 3. A 63-year-old male, who is a chronic alcoholic presents with complaints of recurrent epigastric pain, progressive weight loss, and foul-smelling diarrhoea for the past 6 months. The abdominal pain is persistent and intractable. CT-scan revealed pancreatic calcification and dilatation of the main pancreatic duct. The given condition is likely to be caused due to disturbance in which of the following phases of nutrient absorption?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of chronic pancreatitis. In chronic pancreatitis, the phase of intraluminal digestion is affected in which proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into forms suitable for absorption.

Fat malabsorption in patients with chronic pancreatitis is often associated with steatorrhea. Steatorrhea is characterized by excessive faecal fat and bulky, frothy, greasy, yellow, or clay-coloured stools. Chronic malabsorptive disorders commonly occur due to pancreatic insufficiency, celiac disease, and Crohn disease.

Long-standing malabsorptive disease is accompanied by nutritional deficiency, including weight loss, anemia, osteomalacia, and a tendency to bleed.

Malabsorption occurs due to disturbance in at least one of the four phases of nutrient absorption:

* Intraluminal digestion: In this phase, the proteins, carbohydrates, and fats are broken down into suitable forms for absorption. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include chronic pancreatitis and cystic fibrosis.

* Terminal digestion: This phase involves hydrolysis of carbohydrates and peptides by the enzymes in the brush border of the small intestinal mucosa. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include celiac disease, inflammatory bowel disease.

* Transepithelial transport: In this phase nutrients, fluid, and electrolytes are transported across the small intestinal epithelium, and are processed within the epithelium as they pass. Diseases with abnormalities in this phase include cystic fibrosis, celiac disease, and inflammatory bowel disease.

* Lymphatic transport: The absorbed lipids are transported. Abnormality in this phase is seen in Whipple disease.

questions.text: 4. A 60-year-old man, known for an aggressive brain tumor, was brought to the hospital dead. Previously, MRI had shown an infiltrating neoplasm across the cerebral hemispheres and midline, with necrosis and abnormal blood vessels. After autopsy, brain histopathology showed a pseudo-palisade arrangement of tumor cells. Which statement about this tumor is false?

choices.text: IDH mutant type carries poor prognosis comparatively
Majority of the primary glioblastomas have PTEN mutation
The tumor falls under WHO grade IV
Temozolomide is the first-line drug in the management

questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests the diagnosis of Glioblastoma multiforme. IDH mutant type has a better prognosis.

Glioblastoma falls under WHO grade IV of brain tumors

According to the WHO Classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:

Glioblastoma, IDH-wildtype:

* About 90% of cases

* Primary or de novo glioblastoma

* Over 55 years of age

* Mutations: EGFR, PTEN

* Carries poor prognosis

Glioblastoma, IDH-mutant:

* About 10% of cases

* Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma

* Arises in younger patients

* Mutations:p53

* Better prognosis

Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed.

Temozolomide is used as a first-line agent for the management of glioblastoma multiforme. It is used for newly diagnosed cases along with radiotherapy and also used for maintenance therapy.

The histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudopalisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which is characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme).

questions.text: 5. A 24-year-old P2L2 complains of breast pain and tenderness for 2 months. She last delivered a healthy, 2.8Kg male fetus a year ago. On a mammogram, multiple ill-defined masses were seen. The biopsy shows the following image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of Cystic neutrophilic Granulomatous mastitis, which is caused by Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii. The biopsy images show a non-caseating granuloma (A) and cystic spaces surrounded by neutrophils (C).

Granulomatous mastitis is a benign, self-limiting, inflammatory breast disease that was earlier considered idiopathic. However, an association between a distinct histological pattern termed cystic neutrophilic granulomatous mastitis (CNGM) and Corynebacterium kroppenstedtii infection has been recently theorized.

This condition most commonly affects women of early reproductive age, usually arising within a few years after delivery. Clinically, it can present as one or more inflammatory breast lumps, either centrally or peripherally located and with or without associated abscesses.

Additional signs may include skin breakdown, retraction of the nipple, sinus tract formation, peau d’orange appearance, and swollen axillary lymph nodes. Diagnosis of idiopathic granulomatous mastitis (IGM) is confirmed through needle biopsy of the affected mass. Histologically, CNGM often shows lipogranulomas with cystic spaces and neutrophilic infiltrates.

For symptomatic patients and those with infection, NSAIDs and antibiotics, with or without drainage, are indicated. If symptoms persist or progress, prednisolone (oral or topical), with or without methotrexate, has been shown to aid in the regression of IGM. A major milk duct excision is necessary for patients with a mammary duct fistula, and excision of chronic abscess cavities is performed in cases of recurrence

Other options:

Option A: Lactational mastitis is caused by S. aureus. This would be seen in actively breastfeeding women and frequently presents with an abscess. Histopathology usually reveals a neutrophilic predominance and not a granulomatous picture like in the biopsy image above.

Option B: Tubercular mastitis is a close differential, but histology should show caseating granulomas, which is not the case here. However, to rule out TB, along with histopathology, evidence on imaging and microbiological analysis and GeneXpert is required to establish a diagnosis. 

Option D: Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

questions.text:
6. Match the following histopathological images with their appropriate findings:

a. Hirano body

b. Bunina body

c. Pick body

d. Lewy body
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-d, 2-a, 3-c, 4-b.

Lewy bodies are single or multiple intracytoplasmic, round to elongated, eosinophilic inclusions that often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo. Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells.

Hirano body refers to intracellular, rod-like structures found in neurons, particularly in the hippocampus, that are rich in actin and other proteins and are associated with neurodegenerative conditions like Alzheimer's disease. 

Pick bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, weakly basophilic filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. It contains tau and is seen in frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

Bunina bodies, small eosinophilic inclusions found in the cytoplasm of lower motor neurons, are the definitive pathological hallmark of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a fatal neurodegenerative disease. Under electron microscopy, these bodies present as dense, amorphous material encircled by tubular and vesicular structures. They also exhibit positivity for the protein cystatin C.

questions.text: 8. A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent hematuria and pain in the left flank. He is a chronic smoker and is under medications for hypertension. On examination, the patient appears weak and has a palpable mass in the left flank. His hemoglobin level is found to be 16.5 g/dl. Which of the following mutation will not lead to the condition that the patient has?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario (hematuria, palpable mass, flank pain, along with polycythemia) is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). MSH2 mutation is not associated with RCC.

Renal cell carcinoma can be sporadic or inherited. Various mutations are implicated in familial cancers. The most common mutation is the VHL mutation (clear cell RCC).

Other mutations that can cause renal cell carcinoma include MET mutation (Papillary type RCC), BHD mutation (Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome), and Xp11 translocation (a subtype that occurs in young patients due to overexpression of TFE3 transcription factor).

MSH2 mutation results in DNA mismatch repair, which causes colon cancers, including familial hereditary nonpolyposis colon carcinoma and endometrial cancers.

Tobacco is the leading risk factor for renal cell carcinoma. Other risk factors include obesity and hypertension. Patients with ESRD, chronic kidney disease, and tuberous sclerosis also have an increased risk.

questions.text: 9. Over the last 3 months, an adult man has experienced difficulty swallowing with a feeling of food getting stuck below his throat during meals, postprandial vomiting, and a burning sensation in his chest. His symptoms do not improve on taking proton pump inhibitors (PPIs). A histopathological sample from his upper GI endoscopy is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of dysphagia, food impaction, non-responsiveness to PPI therapy, along with histopathology showing eosinophilic infiltrates, is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Adult patients with eosinophilic esophagitis present with impaction of food, dysphagia, vomiting, and symptoms of reflux. Eosinophilic esophagitis should be suspected in patients with heartburn that does not improve with PPIs. Children with this condition present with nausea, vomiting, chest/abdominal pain, and intolerance/aversion to food.

These patients are usually atopic and may have associated conditions like atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, or moderate peripheral eosinophilia.

The cardinal histological feature is large numbers of intraepithelial eosinophils. Abnormal squamous maturation is also apparent. Other features include eosinophilic microabscesses, eosinophils in superficial layers of squamous mucosa, and lamina propria fibrosis. The histopathological appearance is helpful in differentiating eosinophilic esophagitis from GERD, Crohn's, and other causes of esophagitis.

The “feline” esophagus which resembles the appearance of stacked circular rings, strictures, and linear furrows on esophageal endoscopy is typical of eosinophilic esophagitis and is shown below-



Barium swallow showing the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus-



Treatment includes dietary restrictions of food allergen and topical/systemic corticosteroids.

Other Options-

Option (B): Crohn's disease of the esophagus is considered in the differential diagnosis of esophagitis and histopathological examination is required to confirm the diagnosis. On microscopy, it shows abundant neutrophils that infiltrate and damage the crypt epithelium forming clusters of neutrophils called crypt abscesses. Mucosal architecture is distorted.

Option (C): Reflux esophagitis too can present with heartburn. However, these patients are responsive to PPI treatment (unlike the given scenario). Histopathology showing basal zone hyperplasia and elongation of lamina propria papillae are common. Chronic GERD leads to intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa which is known as Barrett's esophagus.

Option (D): Infectious esophagitis - The most common infectious etiology for esophagitis in debilitated and immunosuppressed patients are herpes simplex virus, cytomegalovirus, and candida esophagitis. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection and from the base of the ulcer in cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

* HSV causes punched out ulcers with cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies on microscopy.

* CMV causes shallow ulcerations and characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions on microscopy.

* Candidiasis, in its most advanced form, is characterized by the adherent, gray-white pseudomembranes.

questions.text: 10. A 58-year-old man presents with a single, thickened, gray-white opaque plaque on the shaft of the penis. Biopsy of the plaque is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history and the biopsy showing koilocytic atypia and dysplastic cells point towards the diagnosis of Bowen disease.

Bowen disease typically manifests in older men, commonly affecting the penile shaft and scrotum. In these areas, it appears as a solitary, thick, gray-white, opaque plaque. Less frequently, when the glans is affected, the lesion presents as a velvety red patch.

Histologically, the lesion is characterized by dysplastic squamous cells. These cells exhibit large, hyperchromatic, and irregular nuclei, and they lack orderly maturation. Numerous mitoses, some of which are atypical, are also observed. In 10% of patients, Bowen disease progresses to infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma.



Premalignant lesions of invasive penile SCC:

* Erythroplasia of Queyrat

* Condyloma acuminatum

* Bowen's disease

Bowenoid papulosis occurs in young, sexually active adults. It presents as multiple reddish-brown papular lesions, and it is histologically indistinguishable from Bowen's disease, but virtually never develops into invasive carcinoma.

Other Options

Option A: Erythroplasia of Queyrat- Shows full-thickness epithelial dysplasia with loss of maturation, nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and numerous mitoses, but an intact basement membrane, consistent with carcinoma in situ. It occurs over the glans penis, not the penile shaft.

Option C: Invasive penile carcinoma- Shows malignant squamous cells invading beyond the basement membrane into the underlying stroma, forming keratin pearls, nests, and sheets with nuclear atypia, pleomorphism, and frequent mitoses

Option D: Lichen slerosus- Shows thinning of the epidermis with loss of rete ridges, basal cell vacuolar degeneration, homogenized (hyalinized) collagen in the upper dermis, and a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate beneath this zone.

12. A 50-year-old man was recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the colon. While explaining the pathogenesis of the disease to him, which of the following would you mention as the "first hit" in the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence?

LOH - Loss of heterozygosity
questions.solution:
The mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21 is the "first hit" in the classical adenoma-carcinoma sequence. 

Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract. The pathogenesis of colon cancer can be explained by three distinct pathways of genomic instability:

* Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/Classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence

* Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI)

* CpG island methylator phenotype pathway.

Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence is the most common pathway, accounting for 80% of sporadic cancers. The "first-hit" in this pathway is the inherited or acquired mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21.

 

Both copies of the APC gene must be inactivated. The "second hit" is due to methylation abnormalities and inactivation of the normal β-catenin. The loss of the second APC allele follows the "second hit."

 

Mutations of KRAS on chromosome 12p12, TP53 on chromosome 17p13, and LOH at chromosome 18q21 are also involved in further steps of the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence.

 

Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI) occurs in patients with DNA mismatch repair deficiency, leading to the accumulation of mutations in microsatellite repeats. The main pathogenic mechanisms are mutations of type II TGF-β receptor leading to uncontrolled cell growth, and loss of pro-apoptotic BAX, which may enhance the survival of genetically abnormal clones.

 

CpG island hypermethylation phenotype (CIMP) - In these tumours, the MLH1 promoter region is typically hypermethylated, thus reducing MLH1 expression and repair function. Activating mutations in the oncogene BRAF are common in these cancers.

 

KRAS and TP53 are not typically mutated. The combination of MSI, BRAF mutation, and methylation of specific targets, such as MLH1, is the signature of this pathway of carcinogenesis.

questions.text: 13. Pituitary adenoma with mucocutaneous myxomas and pigmentary nevi are features of ____________

14. A 62-year-old chronic smoker is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung and is found to have hypercalcemia on laboratory investigation. Which is the most likely mechanism by which he has developed this hypercalcemia?

PTH-rP: Parathyroid hormone-related protein

choices.text: Vitamin D secretion by the tumor
Bone resorption due to skeletal metastasis

questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is one of the most common paraneoplastic syndromes associated with squamous cell cancer (SCC) of the lung. Increased levels of PTH-rP (Parathyroid hormone-related protein) are the most likely mechanism of his hypercalcemia. 

 

Hypercalcemia is a common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with many tumors. This can occur by several mechanisms, the most common ones being the release of PTH-rP and vitamin D. Hypercalcemia due to PTH-rP is very common in squamous cell tumors, like those of the lung, breast, and kidney. 

 

Osteolysis due to bony metastasis and cancers like multiple myeloma can also result in hypercalcemia, but this is not considered a paraneoplastic syndrome. It is interesting to note that hypercalcemia is associated with cancer more often than it is with hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other options: 

Option (A): Inhibition of osteoclasts is the mechanism of action of bisphosphonates. These are the first-line drugs of choice to treat hypercalcemia associated with malignancy.

 

Option (B): Vitamin D secretion as a paraneoplastic mechanism of hypercalcemia can be seen in some lymphomas. It is not the mechanism seen in SCCs.

 

Option (C): Bone resorption due to skeletal metastasis can cause hypercalcemia. Although bone metastasis can be seen in SCC of the lung, it is not the most likely mechanism of hypercalcemia in these patients.

questions.text: 15. An autopsy was conducted for a 9-year-old boy who died after recurrent, intractable seizures. MRI brain performed before death revealed multiple cortical tubers. On examination of the brain, small masses bulging into the ventricles are seen. This pathological feature is best described as:
questions.solution:
The pathological finding in the given scenario is described as candle-gutterings.

The given scenario is suggestive of tuberous sclerosis. Tuberous sclerosis is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterised by the presence of benign congenital tumors in multiple organs. 

The pathogenesis of tuberous sclerosis involves a mutation in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16. Loss-of-function mutations of these tumor suppressor genes (TSC1 and TSC2) are present.

Tumours associated with tuberous sclerosis include: renal angiomyolipomas, retinal glial hamartomas, cortical hamartomas, pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis, and cardiac rhabdomyomas.

Cutaneous lesions present as angiofibromas, shagreen patches (localized leathery thickenings), ash-leaf patches (hypopigmented areas), and subungual fibromas.

Cortical hamartomas in tuberous sclerosis complex are firm "tubers" made of disorganized neurons. Some cells are dysplastic, appearing as an intermediate between glia and neurons, expressing both neuronal and glial filaments. Similar hamartomas, called "candle-gutterings," are found as subependymal nodules. 

Other Options:

Option A: Gyri with spongy degeneration are seen in Creutzfeldt–Jakob Disease.

Option C: Butterfly glioma is seen in glioblastoma multiforme.

Option D: Cobblestone cortex is seen in cobblestone lissencephaly.

Pearl PM2489: Cutaneous lesions of Tuberous sclerosis

Tuberous sclerosis (TS) is also known as tuberous sclerosis complex or Bourneville disease. It is a neurocutaneous disorder (phakomatosis) characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors of the embryonic ectoderm (e.g. skin, eyes, and nervous system). It is an autosomal dominant condition.  The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Tuberous sclerosis presents in childhood with a triad (Vogt triad). The triad comprises of:

* Seizures

* Mental retardation

* Adenoma sebaceum

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region. Shagreen is shark skin used as a decorative material present in the right image given below.



The typical hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules on the trunk and extremities are seen in 90% of the patients. It is visualized by the use of a wood ultraviolet lamp.



Facial angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum) develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.



Periungual fibroma are small fibromas or nodules of skin, which form around fingernails or toenails in some adolescent patients



Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text: 16. A 52-year-old diabetic woman presented with recurrent flank pain and fever with chills. A CECT abdomen revealed a characteristic "bear paw sign." A renal biopsy was done, following which the kidney was resected. The gross specimen displayed large yellowish-orange nodules. Which biopsy finding is most likely?

choices.text: Thyroidization of tubules in the renal cortex
Enlarged tubular epithelial cells with nuclear inclusions

questions.solution:
The most likely biopsy finding for this condition is the accumulation of lipid-laden foamy macrophages.

The history and the clinical features are suggestive of xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis. It is characterised by foamy macrophages, plasma cells, lymphocytes, and a few giant cells. It is associated with the bear claw sign in CT and yellowish nodules on the gross specimen. 

Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is a relatively rare form of chronic pyelonephritis characterised by the accumulation of foamy macrophages intermingled with plasma cells, lymphocytes, polymorphonuclear leukocytes, and occasional giant cells. It is associated with Proteus infection in middle-aged females with DM.



The lesions sometimes produce large, yellowish-orange nodules that may be grossly confused with renal cell carcinoma. On CT, there is a characteristic "Bear Paw" sign. Subcapsular nephrectomy is the definitive treatment



Other Options:

Option A: Thyroidization of tubules in the cortex is a histopathological finding of chronic pyelonephritis. Kidneys in chronic pyelonephritis are irregularly scarred and asymmetric. The corticomedullary scars are coarse with dilated, blunted calyces and papillary flattening.

Option C: Histopathology shows enlarged tubular epithelial cell nuclei, leading to nuclear enlargement and intranuclear inclusions visible by light microscopy, which is seen in polyoma virus nephropathy. Polyomavirus is a viral pathogen causing pyelonephritis in kidney allografts. 

Option D: Histopathology showing eosinophilic and mononuclear infiltrates is suggestive of drug-induced nephropathy. Acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) is an immune-mediated inflammation of the kidney interstitium and tubules, most commonly triggered by medications such as antibiotics, NSAIDs, and proton pump inhibitors.

questions.text: 17. A 62-year-old man presents with progressive difficulty climbing stairs, frequent falls, gripping issues, and occasional choking. Examination reveals weakness in the quadriceps and distal upper limb muscles. Labs show mildly elevated serum creatine kinase. The muscle biopsy is shown below. What's the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of proximal (quadriceps) and distal (finger flexor) weakness, dysphagia, mildly elevated CK, and muscle biopsy showing rimmed vacuoles with basophilic inclusions strongly suggests inclusion body myositis.

Inclusion body myositis (IBM) is a condition that primarily affects individuals in late adulthood, typically those over 50 years old. It is recognized as the most prevalent inflammatory myopathy in patients aged 65 and above.

Clinical Presentation: Most individuals with IBM experience a gradual worsening of muscle weakness, which is usually most pronounced in the quadriceps and the muscles of the distal upper extremities. Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) due to involvement of the esophageal and pharyngeal muscles is also a common symptom.

Laboratory Findings: Laboratory tests often reveal moderately elevated creatine kinase levels. While most autoantibodies associated with myositis are typically absent, a recently identified antibody to cytosolic 5’-nucleotidase 1A (cN1A) serves as a valuable marker, present in approximately half of the affected patients.

Key characteristics for the diagnosis of inclusion body myositis include:

* Abnormal Cytoplasmic Inclusions: "Rimmed vacuoles" (as shown in the question image marked by arrows) are present.

* Tubulofilamentous Inclusions: These are observable in myofibers via electron microscopy.

* Cytoplasmic inclusions contain proteins associated with neurodegenerative diseases, such as beta-amyloid, TDP-43, and ubiquitin.

* Endomysial fibrosis and fatty replacement are evident, reflecting a chronic disease course.

* Patchy, often endomysial, mononuclear inflammatory cell infiltrates rich in CD8+ T cells.

* Increased sarcolemmal expression of major histocompatibility complex class I antigens.

* Focal invasion of normal-appearing myofibers by inflammatory cells.

* Admixture of degenerating and regenerating myofibers.

questions.text: 18. A 5-year-old girl with cyclical vaginal bleeding and irregular skin macules presents to the OPD with complaints of bony pain in her right leg. The bone biopsy image is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical vignette with the histopathological image given above suggests a diagnosis of fibrous dysplasia among the given options. 

The clinical history of precocious puberty and café-au-lait skin pigmentation with bony pain is suggestive of McCune-Albright Syndrome, which often has a component of polyostotic fibrous dysplasia. The image showing curvilinear trabeculae of woven bone with a lack of osteoblastic rimming is typical of fibrous dysplasia.

Fibrous dysplasia is caused by a somatic activating mutation in the GNAS1 gene. This mutation leads to abnormal bone development and can also result in café-au-lait skin pigmentation due to increased signaling through the melanocyte-stimulating hormone receptor, as well as various endocrine abnormalities

It is characterized by the presence of either monostotic (single bone) or polyostotic (multiple bones) expanding lesions composed of bone-forming mesenchymal tissue. 

Radiological findings:

* Well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesions

* A hazy, ground-glass appearance is seen in the majority of cases

* Shepherd's crook deformity - Expansion with marked varus in the proximal femur



McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS) is a clinical triad comprising polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café-au-lait spots, and autonomous endocrine hyperfunction. The most common endocrine manifestation is isosexual precocious puberty in girls. Other possible endocrinopathies include thyrotoxicosis, Cushing’s syndrome, acromegaly, hyperparathyroidism, hyperprolactinemia, and precocious puberty in boys.

Other Options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma most commonly occurs in the metaphysis of long bones and shows a bimodal age distribution with a predilection to affect men of less than 20 years of age. Radiographically, it shows the Codman triangle. Pleomorphic cells producing primitive woven bone and osteoid are histological features of osteosarcoma.



Option C: Mononuclear tumor cells & giant cells with multiple nuclei are histological features of giant cell tumors or osteoclastoma. They affect young adults and arise from the epiphysis of long bones. X-ray shows a characteristic soap bubble appearance. Histological features are demonstrated below.



Option D: Ewing’s sarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone in patients of less than 10 years of age. Histopathologically, it shows primitive small, round blue cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm.

19. A middle-aged woman undergoes resection of an ovarian tumor. After the histopathological examination of the resected specimen the pathologist comes to the diagnosis of Brenner tumor. * Call Exner bodies

The correct answer is 2- Walthard cell rests, 4- Transitional epithelium, and 5- Coffee bean nuclei.

Brenner tumour is an uncommon solid fibroepithelial tumour. Its gross appearance often mimics an ovarian fibroma, with a cut surface that is grey and yellowish-grey. These tumours are generally unilateral, small to moderate in size, and mostly benign, without any endocrine function. 

Clinically, Brenner tumours typically affect women around menopause, often presenting with postmenopausal bleeding. In some instances, they may be associated with ascites and hydrothorax, a condition known as pseudo-Meigs Syndrome. 

Histologically, the tumour is characterised by a fibrous tissue background, with interspersed nests of transitional epithelium, also known as Walthard cell rests, within the fibrous tissue. These epithelial cells have nuclei with a distinctive longitudinal groove, giving them an appearance resembling a coffee bean.

The image below shows Walthard cell rests and coffee bean nuclei, which are pathognomic of Brenner's tumour.

questions.text: 20. A 45-year-old man presents with jaundice and pruritus. He has been on treatment for ulcerative colitis for many years. Investigations showed elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. MRCP showed beading in the bile ducts. Biopsy finding reveals the following appearance of the bile duct. What is the likely diagnosis?

The given image shows onion-skin fibrosis surrounding the bile duct which is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis. Beading of the bile ducts seen on MRCP is also suggestive of the diagnosis.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilation of preserved segments.

* Small intrahepatic bile ducts are not directly involved by inflammation. However, they exhibit mild injury and prominent ductular reaction due to cholestasis.

questions.text: 22. A 24-year-old teacher presented with weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema for the past 6 months and was diagnosed with a protein-losing enteropathy. The hispathological image of the gastric tissue is given below. Which of the following growth factors is primarily responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the histological image with the arrow mark showing hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells, cystically dilated glands which are elongated (with a corkscrew-like appearance) are suggestive of Ménétrier disease, which occurs due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor α (TGF-α).

Menetrier disease:

Menetrier disease is one of the causes of hypertrophic gastropathy. It is characterized by irregular enlargement of the gastric rugae in the body and fundus but the antrum is generally spared. It is associated with diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar epithelium and hypoproteinemia due to protein-losing enteropathy.

Symptoms such as weight loss, diarrhea, and peripheral edema, are commonly present. The features of Ménétrier disease in children are similar to those in adults, but the pediatric disease is usually self-limited and often occurs after an episode of respiratory infection. There is an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma in adults.

Treatment of Ménétrier disease is mainly supportive, with intravenous albumin and parenteral nutritional supplementation. Gastrectomy may be required in severe cases. Drugs that block TGF-α-mediated activation of the epidermal growth factor receptor are also being tried.

questions.text: 23. A 35-year-old woman presents with recurrent headaches and occasional seizures. MRI brain shows a well-circumscribed lesion in the cerebral cortex. The biopsy of the lesion is shown below. This lesion is commonly associated with which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
The lesion described in the given scenario is a cavernous hemangioma and is commonly associated with Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome.

Cavernous hemangiomas are characterized by large, dilated vascular channels. Unlike some other types, these hemangiomas are often infiltrative, frequently affecting deep structures, and typically do not regress spontaneously. 

Histologically, they appear as sharply delineated but unencapsulated masses, consisting of large, blood-filled vascular spaces separated by a connective tissue stroma. Cavernous hemangiomas are also recognized as a feature of von Hippel-Lindau disease.



Von Hippel-Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant disease. The gene associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease, called VHL, is a tumor-suppressor gene located on chromosome 3p. 

Patients with this disease are at increased risk of developing hemangioblastomas of the CNS; cysts that involve the pancreas, liver, and kidneys; renal cell carcinomas; and pheochromocytomas.

questions.text: 24. A chronic alcoholic patient presented with yellowish discoloration of the eyes and abdominal pain. On examination, there is tender hepatomegaly. Histopathological examination of the liver revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes composed of intermediate filaments. Identify the inclusion bodies.
questions.solution:
Mallory hyaline bodies are the inclusion bodies in hepatocytes present in this patient.

The clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with jaundice, abdominal pain, and tender hepatomegaly is suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies and they contain intermediate filaments. 

The liver undergoes inflammation and fibrosis in alcoholic hepatitis. This leads to injured and swollen hepatocytes with cleared-out cytoplasm and cytoskeletal damage. These hepatocytes are called ballooned hepatocytes. When the cytoskeletal damage is extensive, there is the formation of Mallory Denk/ Mallory hyaline bodies. These are remnants of partially degraded intermediate filaments and are composed of keratin 8 and keratin 18.

Mallory hyaline bodies are seen in:

* Wilson disease

* Primary biliary cirrhosis

* Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis(NASH)

* Hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.text: 26. 35 year old female presents with a 1 cm nodule on her labia which shows ulceration. On subsequent biopsy the following image is obtained. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image of a vulval lesion, which resembles an intraductal papilloma of the breast is a hidradenoma.

Hidradenoma is a benign tumor arising from apocrine glands, most often presenting as a sharply circumscribed nodule on the labia majora or interlabial folds. Clinically, it may be mistaken for carcinoma because of its tendency to ulcerate, though it rarely exceeds 1 cm in size.

Histologically, hidradenoma shows cystic spaces with papillary adenomatous masses, closely resembling intraductal papilloma of the breast. The papillae are lined by two distinct cell layers: an outer columnar secretory layer and an inner myoepithelial layer, the latter being characteristic of sweat gland tumors. * Papilloma with fibrovascular core

Duct ectasia is the focal dilatation of the lactiferous ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is strongly associated with smoking.

Intraductal papilloma is a benign, proliferative breast disorder without atypia. It is defined as localised hyperplasia of the ductal epithelium within the duct. It comprises a central fibrovascular core and papillary projections of the epithelium and myoepithelial cells.

This condition is linked to a moderately elevated risk of developing carcinoma and is categorized into two types: atypical ductal hyperplasia and atypical lobular hyperplasia.

questions.text: 30. A 45-year-old man is admitted to the ICU with septic shock. After 2 days, he develops oliguria and rising serum creatinine. Urinalysis reveals the presence of urinary casts as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The given clinical scenario and the urinalysis showing muddy brown cast point towards the diagnosis of acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

The given scenario describes a patient in septic shock. Septic shock causes renal hypoperfusion and ischemia. This damages tubular epithelial cells, which is the hallmark of ischemic ATN.

In patients with ATN, urinalysis can show muddy brown granular casts. These are formed by sloughed, necrotic tubular epithelial cells and proteins.

The cause of Whipple disease is a gram-positive actinomycete, named Tropheryma whipplei. The macrophages stain positive with periodic acid–Schiff (PAS).

The morphologic hallmark of Whipple disease is a dense accumulation of distended, foamy macrophages in the small intestinal lamina propria. Macrophages contain periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive, diastase-resistant granules that represent lysosomes stuffed with partially digested bacteria.

34. Choose the correct statements regarding Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

* It most commonly causes hyperthyroidism.

* Antibodies against thyroid peroxidase are seen. 

* Thyroid profile shows low TSH and high T4.

* It is associated with thyroid lymphomas.

TSH - Thyroid-stimulating hormone

T4 - Thyroxine
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are correct regarding Hashimoto's thyroiditis. It is characterized by the presence of antibodies against thyroid peroxidase and is associated with thyroid lymphomas.

Statements 1 and 3 are false. Hashimoto's thyroiditis, most commonly causing hypothyroidism (not hyperthyroidism), is associated with high TSH and low T4 levels (not low TSH and high T4). 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure.

It occurs most commonly among middle-aged women. It is associated with malignant lymphoma of thyroid.

Patients present with painless diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism. However, initially few patients may present with a transient hyperthyroid state, known as hashitoxicosis, due to the release of thyroid hormones by disruption of the thyroid follicles.

Laboratory investigations:

* T3 and T4 are low

* TSH is raised

* Presence of autoantibodies against:

* Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)

* Thyroglobulin

Histopathology of Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

* Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centres.

questions.text: 35. An elderly man presents with acute chest pain. He was diagnosed with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction and later died from sudden cardiac death. An autopsy was conducted which showed the following cells in the vessel wall of his left main coronary artery. These cells would have ingested which substance?

The cells marked in the image above are the foam cells in atheromatous plaques and they ingest lipoproteins. They are known as lipid-laden monocytes/ macrophages or smooth muscle cells within the plaques.

These cells ingest lipoproteins accumulated within the intima of the vessel wall. questions.text: 38. The histopathological examination of a lung biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most common manifestation of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The histopathology section shows golden-brown rod-like structures with knobbed or beaded ends known as asbestos bodies. This is indicative of asbestosis and the most common manifestation seen in this are pleural plaques.

Asbestosis occurs due to the inhalation of crystalline hydrated silicates (asbestos). It occurs in two distinct geometric forms, serpentine and amphibole. It is characterized by diffuse parenchymal interstitial fibrosis. It usually begins in the lower lobes of the lungs and may present with dyspnea and cough, usually after 20-30 years of exposure. 

Pleural plaques of dense collagen that may be calcified are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure. They involve the anterior and posterolateral aspects of the parietal pleura and the diaphragmatic domes. Other asbestos-related diseases include recurrent pleural effusions, lung carcinoma, mesothelioma, and rarely diffuse visceral pleural fibrosis in advanced cases.

Asbestos bodies are a hallmark finding. They appear as golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods. These are formed when the asbestos fibers are phagocytosed by the macrophages and are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin.

questions.text: 39. A 25 year old man with a soft tissue tumor over his forearm undergoes a biopsy, which is shown below. Molecular studies show a t(x:18)(p11:q11) translocation.What is the probable diagnosis and gene fusion?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is diagnostic of synovial sarcoma, which shows SS18-SSX1 gene fusion.

The histopathological image shows sheets of uniform spindle cells with scant cytoplasm and dense chromatin, along with molecular studies indicating a t(x:18)(p11:q11) translocation, which is diagnostic of Synovial sarcoma.   It occurs in young people with a median age of 35 years, compared to other soft tissue sarcomas affecting the older population. They usually occur in the distal extremities, including the hand and foot. It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of the foot. They often present as small, indolent masses, with pain being the chief complaint rather than a growing mass.

Histopathologically, it is commonly biphasic with both spindled and epithelial components demonstrable on both light microscopy and immunohistochemistry. Monophasic sarcomas show uniform spindle cells with little cytoplasm but dense chromatin in tightly packed fascicles.

A chromosomal translocation t(x;18) (p11;q11) that produces fusion of the SS18 gene to one of three SSX genes is present in most synovial sarcomas. Immunohistochemistry is useful in diagnosing these tumours as the epithelial antigens (keratins) differentiate synovial sarcomas from other sarcomas. It may show Lymph nodal spread. FISH marker- SS18.

Treatment and prognosis for synovial sarcoma are similar to those of Undifferentiated Pleomorphic Sarcoma (UPS). Treatment involves a wide resection. Chemotherapy can be useful, but not at the cost of delaying resection. Radiation can be used as an adjuvant for large tumors and can be administered pre-operatively or post-operatively.

questions.text: 40. A 30-year-old male presented with an asymptomatic unilateral neck mass. Biopsy revealed a tumor arising from carotid body bifurcation which secreted norepinephrine. Various other laboratory and radiological investigations rule out pheochromocytoma in this patient. Which of the following syndrome would cause this tumor without pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Hereditary paraganglioma type 3  is associated with isolated paraganglioma without pheochromocytoma. Type 1 and 4 are associated with both pheochromocytoma and paragangliomas

Paragangliomas are neuroendocrine cell tumors arising from sympathetic or parasympathetic ganglia. Sympathetic paraganglioma secretes catecholamines whilst parasympathetic are silent. They may be incidentally detected. Around 70% of extra-adrenal paragangliomas occur in the head and neck.

Adrenal medullary pheochromocytomas are the most common paraganglioma.

Paragangliomas typically develop in two locations:

* Paravertebral paraganglia (organ of Zuckerkandl). These tumors have sympathetic connections and stain positively for chromaffin, as they produce catecholamines.

* Paraganglia related to the great vessels of the head and neck, especially the aorticopulmonary chain, including the carotid bodies (carotid body tumor), aortic bodies, jugulotympanic ganglia ( glomus tympanicum or jugulare), the vagus nerve, and clusters located around the oral cavity, nose, nasopharynx, larynx, and orbit. These have parasympathetic innervation and do not usually produce catecholamines.

The carotid body tumor is a parasympathetic paraganglioma. It is usually less than 6 cm in diameter and arises around the bifurcation of the common carotid artery. The tumor is red-pink to brown colored, and the microscopic features show nests (zellballen) of round to oval chief cells with abundant, clear or granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm and uniform, round to ovoid nuclei, surrounded by delicate vascular septae. There is scanty cellular pleomorphism and mitoses. The chief cells stain positive for chromogranin, synaptophysin, neuron-specific enolase, CD56, and CD57.

The supporting spindle-shaped stromal cells called sustentacular cells are positive for S-100 protein.

Electron microscopy shows well-demarcated neuroendocrine granules in paravertebral, functioning tumors.

questions.text: 41. A 50-year-old female complains of progressive lower abdominal pain associated with frequent and painful urination. Under antibiotic coverage, cystoscopic examination shows soft, yellow, and raised mucosal plaques. The biopsy study from one of the lesions is given below. The clinical condition is described in the given case scenario is Malakoplakia. Escherichia coli is the most common organism involved in this condition.

Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function, commonly affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and the central nervous system.

Malakoplakia is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species.   Grossly, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques, often misdiagnosed clinically as malignancy. Microscopically, they are composed of large, foamy macrophages mixed with occasional multinucleate giant cells and lymphocytes.

In addition, intracellular deposition of calcium and iron within enlarged lysosomes forms laminated basophilic concretions, known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies, pathognomonic of malakoplakia.The following image shows the Michaelis–Gutmann bodies marked in black arrows.

questions.text: 43. A 63-year-old woman presented with weakness and abdominal pain. She reported a loss of 10 Kgs of weight in the past month. Physical examination revealed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The patient died a few months later. Gross specimen of the liver is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the gross specimen showing multiple nodular lesions of variable size are suggestive of metastatic carcinoma of the liver.

Liver metastasis is more common than the primary tumour of the liver. Gross appearance shows multiple nodular lesions of variable size, replacing much of the normal parenchyma and can even lead to an increase in the weight of the liver. In most cases, the only clinical sign is hepatomegaly. However, in cases associated with massive destruction of the liver or obstruction of the bile duct, jaundice and elevations of liver enzymes may occur. The most common primary sources include the colon, breast, lung, and pancreas, although any cancer in any site may spread to the liver.

Other options:

Option A: Angiosarcoma of the liver is usually seen in individuals having occupational exposure to agents such as vinyl chloride, arsenic, or thorotrast. The gross specimen of the liver (as shown in the image below) shows large, fleshy masses of red-tan to gray-white tissue with margins blurring into surrounding structures. Necrosis and haemorrhage are common(arrows). The asterisk marks the normal liver tissue.



Option C: Cholangiocarcinoma may arise either from extrahepatic or intrahepatic bile ducts. Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma usually occurs in the noncirrhotic liver and usually forms a firm gray-white mass.

The gross specimen of the liver usually shows a large, firm, well-demarcated white-tan nodule with central whitish scarred tissue (asterisk), and the liver tissue surrounding the lesion in most cases is non-cirrhotic (image A). In some cases, periductal infiltration may be seen (arrows, in the second image below).





Option D: Primary hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has a peak incidence around 20 to 40 years of age and is predominantly seen in men. There is usually a history of predisposing conditions such as HBV/HCV infections, alcohol, and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. The gross appearance shows unifocal or multifocal, or diffusely infiltrative lesions that can be paler than the surrounding tissue. The lesions may be greenish due to the presence of bile.

Neuroblastomas arise from the neural crest cells and are the most common intra-abdominal and extracranial solid tumors in children. Most patients present before the age of 5 years. Patients who present with the disease before the age of 18 months have a significantly better prognosis. Rearrangement or deletion of the short arm of chromosome 1 is seen in many patients. The MYCN gene is used as a biomarker for risk stratification. Expression of this oncogene, which is seen in about 20% of the patients, is associated with aggressive disease. Hyperdiploidy is associated with a favorable prognosis in children. Loss of heterozygosity in 1p, 11q, 14q, and gain of 17q are associated with a worse prognosis.

Histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. Histologically, classic neuroblastomas are composed of small, primitive-appearing cells with dark nuclei, scant cytoplasm, and poorly defined cell borders growing in solid sheets. Typically, Homer-Wright pseudorosettes can be found in which tumor cells are concentrically arranged about a central space filled with neuropil.

46. A 50-year old patient comes to the surgical outpatient department with complaints of epigastric pain, weight loss, vomiting, diabetes, and jaundice. An ERCP was performed which showed dilatation of the main pancreatic duct, with a classic fish-mouth appearance of the ampulla. Which of the following statements is false about the diagnosis?

ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs). The false statement is that KRAS mutations are characteristic in IPMNs.

IPMNs are cystic neoplasms of the pancreas. They are premalignant neoplasms (Option A). They are characteristically more common in men (Option C) and occur in the pancreatic head (Option D). They are mucin-producing tumors of large ducts in the pancreas. The absence of dense "ovarian" stroma and involvement of the pancreatic duct help differentiate IPMNs from mucinous cystic neoplasms

Oncogenic mutations that are seen are:

* Oncogenic mutations of GNAS encoding the GSα subunit are characteristic.

* K-RAS is the most common in approximately 80% of cases

* Loss of function mutations of RNF43 in 50% of cases

It presents with epigastric discomfort, pain, nausea, and vomiting, weight loss, diabetes, jaundice, and fistulae. 

Histopathological findings of the head of the pancreas show prominent papillary neoplasm involving the main pancreatic duct. 

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is the investigation of choice. On ERCP, dilatation of the main pancreatic duct or its branches is observed. Diagnostic features like the fish-mouth appearance (gaping ampulla with extrusion of mucin) may be observed.

Other cystic neoplasms of the pancreas are:

* Serous cystic neoplasms - are common in women. Inactivation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p is most common.

* Mucinous cystic neoplasms - are common in women. Oncogenic KRAS mutations are seen in half the cases. Characteristic "ovarian" stroma appearance is seen.

* Solid-pseudopapillary neoplasm - seen in young women. Activating mutations of CTNNB1 (β-catenin) are present.

questions.text: 47. A nerve stimulation study was done for a patient with chronic fatigue, and the results are shown in the graph below. What is the likely diagnosis and what else will you screen for in this patient?

choices.text: Lambert Eaton syndrome, Small cell lung cancer
Myasthenia gravis, Small cell lung cancer

questions.solution:
The given graph shows a decremental response to repeated nerve stimulation. This finding, along with the history of fatigue, makes myasthenia gravis the likely diagnosis. Thymoma is closely associated with myasthenia gravis and should be screened for in this patient. 

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR is mediated by the thymus.

The myoid (muscle-like) cells present in the thymus express AChRs on their surface and are postulated to provide the autoantigen that triggers this autoimmune reaction. There is some thymic abnormality in most patients with MG.

Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients. Thymoma is seen as an enlargement of the thymus in the anterior mediastinum on CT chest.

MG usually occurs in females in their 20s and 30s.  Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increase on repeated use or late in the day and improve on rest.

The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles, are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. 

The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include:

* Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay 

* Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response

* Block and jitter response on single-fiber EMG

* Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of an anticholinesterase such as edrophonium

* Positive ice-pack test: improvement of ptosis on the application of an ice-pack on the affected eye

Histopathology: Benign thymoma (medullary type) features neoplastic epithelial cells with swirling patterns, bland oval/elongated nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli, and few reactive lymphoid cells.

Malignant thymoma shows polygonal epithelial cells, round/oval bland nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli, and numerous reactive lymphoid cells. Its morphology mirrors benign cortical thymomas, but it is locally aggressive, invading adjacent lung and pericardium.

Patients with generalized MG are started on anticholinesterase drugs such as pyridostigmine. They are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Indications for thymectomy in a patient diagnosed with MG include: 

* Presence of thymoma

* Generalized MG with anti-AChR antibodies, even if no thymoma is seen on CT chest

Following thymectomy, immunosuppressive drugs are started based on the clinical status of the patient. 

Other options: 

Lambert-Eaton Syndrome is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach) release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers, ACh presynaptic concentration, and postsynaptic ACh receptors. It presents with an incremental response on repeated nerve stimulation test. Approximately 50% of LEMS cases are associated with malignancy, mainly small-cell lung cancer (SCLC).

questions.text: 48. A 2-month-old infant was diagnosed with pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Electron microscopy of the lung tissue showed type 2 pneumocytes containing small surfactant lamellae with electron-dense cores. The given condition is associated with which of the following gene mutations?
questions.solution:
The presence of abnormal type 2 pneumocytes containing small surfactant lamellae with electron-dense cores, is characteristic of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis associated with ABCA3 mutations.

Surfactant dysfunction disorders:

They are diseases caused due to mutations in genes, which encode proteins involved in surfactant trafficking or secretion. The commonly mutated genes include:

* ATP-binding cassette protein member 3 (ABCA3): It is the most common genetic mutation in surfactant dysfunction disorders. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive mode. The disease usually presents in the first few months of life, rarely in older children. It is associated with rapidly progressive respiratory failure followed by death.

* SFTPC gene: It is the second most commonly mutated, which normally encodes for surfactant protein C. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant mode.

* SFTPB gene: It is the third most commonly mutated gene, which normally encodes for surfactant protein B.  It is inherited in an autosomal recessive mode. The infant is full-term and develops progressive respiratory distress shortly after birth. If early lung transplantation is not done, the infants may die between 3 and 6 months of age.

Morphology:

* The alveoli are filled with pink granular material.

* It is associated with type II pneumocyte hyperplasia, interstitial fibrosis, and alveolar simplification.

* In the case of mutations involving SFTPB or SFTPC genes, immunohistochemical stains show the lack of surfactant proteins B and C, respectively.

* Electron microscopy shows abnormalities in lamellar bodies in type II pneumocytes, in all three types.

* Small lamellar bodies with electron-dense cores are diagnostic for ABCA3 mutation.

questions.text: 49. A patient undergoes TRUS guided biopsy of the prostate gland for suspected malignancy. The Gleason score for two biopsy sites is given as 4 each. Which Gleason grade group does this belong to?
questions.solution:
The patient has an overall Gleason score of 8 (4+4), which classifies it into Gleason grade group 4.

Prostate cancers are classified using the Gleason Grading system. Here, the histopathologist looks at the biopsy sample and, depending on the findings, assigns one Gleason score to the most predominant pattern in the biopsy and a second Gleason score to the second most predominant pattern. Prostate cancers exhibit heterogeneity within the tissue. Thus, two histological areas of the prostate are each scored between 3 and 5. The scores are added to give an overall Gleason score between 6 and 10 which correlates with the likelihood of spread and the prognosis.

The Gleason Score is always a sum of two numbers. If only one Gleason grade is present, then this is doubled. In 2014, the International Society of Urological Pathology (ISUP) released a revised prostate cancer grading system, called the Grade Groups. It is a simpler classification with only five grades (1 to 5).

Highlights of 2014 WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score:

1) Gleason Pattern:

* Pattern 3- Well formed glands

* Pattern 4- Poorly formed/Fused/Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands

* Pattern 5- Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis

* Pattern 1 and 2 are no longer defined

2) Gleason Score: The current Gleason score ranges from 6–10. 

3) Grade group (first score represents the most predominant pattern and the second represents the second most predominant pattern in the biopsy):

Grade group 1: 3 + 3 = 6 Grade group 2: 3 + 4  = 7 Grade group 3: 4 + 3 = 7 Grade group 4: 4 + 4; 3 + 5; or 5 + 3 = 8 Grade group 5: 4 + 5; 5 + 4; or 5 + 5 = 9-10

questions.text: 50. A 50-year-old man presented with the blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. Histopathology of the kidney was as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of diabetic retinopathy with proteinuria and the histopathological image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules with increased mesangial matrix is highly suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease, which occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease is also known as nodular glomerulosclerosis or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis

Mesangial matrix appear as ovoid or spherical, acellular nodules in the periphery of the glomerulus. These nodules are PAS-positive. Capillary loops at the periphery are dilated. Accumulations of hyaline material occurs in the capillary loops (fibrin caps) and bowman capsules (capsular drops).

Other renal lesions that are seen in diabetic nephropathy:

* Glomerular lesions:

* Capillary basement membrane thickening

* Diffuse mesangial sclerosis

* Nodular glomerulosclerosis/Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease

* Renal vascular lesions, mainly hyaline arteriolosclerosis

* Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis

Given below is another histopathology image of diffuse and nodular diabetic glomerulosclerosis (PAS stain). Diffuse increase in mesangial matrix and characteristic acellular PAS-positive nodules are seen.



Other options:

Option A: Diffuse lupus nephritis is the most common form of lupus nephritis (Class IV).

The lesions may be global or diffuse. It is characterized by the proliferation of endothelial, mesangial, and epithelial cells of the involved glomeruli. Subendothelial immune complex deposition forms a circumferential thickening of the capillary wall, resulting in wire-loop lesions.

The histopathology image given below shows a hypercellular glomerulus (endocapillary proliferation). Glomerular capillary loops appear circumferentially thickened, forming a "wire loop" lesion, which is classically seen in diffuse lupus nephritis.



Option B: Renal amyloidosis: The kidney is the most common organ involved in amyloidosis. Glomerular deposits appears as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid. Capillary lumens are obliterated.

Image below shows amyloidosis of the kidney. The glomerular architecture is almost totally obliterated by the massive accumulation of amyloid.



Option D: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with characteristic degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells as well as effacement of foot processes. Histology reveals focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall. Lipid droplets and foam cells are present in the sclerosed area.
